AtlantanThe term "Atlantans" is widely used by both [http://atlanta.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2008/06/23/focus2.html local media] and [http://www.cnn.com/2008/US/weather/03/17/atlanta.tornado/index.html national media].

article.paragraph: Atlanta(IPAc-enEn-us-Atlanta.ogvætˈlæntə, locallyIPAc-enEn-us-Atlanta-local.ogvætˈlænə) is thecapital citycapitalof and the most populouscityin theUnited StatesU.S.U.S. statestateofGeorgia (U.S. state)Georgia, with an estimated 2013 population of 447,841.Atlanta is the cultural and economic center of theAtlanta metropolitan area, home to 5,522,942 people and thetable of United States Metropolitan Statistical Areasninth largest metropolitan areain the United States.Atlanta is thecounty seatofFulton County, GeorgiaFulton County, and a small portion of the city extends eastward intoDeKalb County, GeorgiaDeKalb County.

Atlanta was established in 1837 at the intersection of two railroad lines, and the city rose from the ashes of theAmerican Civil WarCivil Warto become a national center of commerce. In the decades following theAfrican American civil rights movementCivil Rights Movement, during which the city earned a reputation as "too busy to hate" for the progressive views of its citizens and leaders,cite webhttp://www.politifact.com/georgia/statements/2011/jun/28/al-roker/whos-right-cities-lay-claim-civil-rights-cradle-ma/"Who's right? Cities lay claim to civil rights 'cradle' mantle"/'"Atlanta Journal-Constitution''Politifact.comJune 28, 2011May 17, 2012Atlanta attained international prominence. Atlanta is the primary transportation hub of theSoutheastern United States, via highway, railroad, andair transportationair, withHartsfieldJackson Atlanta International Airportbeing theworld's busiest airportsince 1998.cite webhttp://www.atlanta-airport.com/docs/Traffic/200812.pdfMONTHLY AIRPORT TRAFFIC REPORTDecember 2008[[Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport]]December 13, 2010cite newshttp://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2008/03/10/daily44.htmlDOT: Hartsfield-Jackson busiest airport, Delta had 3rd-most passengersMarch 13, 2008cite webhttp://www.allbusiness.com/company-activities-management/company-locations-facilities/6399916-1.htmlTop Industry Publications Rank Atlanta as a LeadingCity for Business. | North America >United States fromAllBusiness.comApril 5, 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20090419091606/http://www.allbusiness.com:80/company-activities-management/company-locations-facilities/6399916-1.html19 April 2009cite webhttp://www.business.gov/states/georgia/local/atlanta.htmlDoing Business in Atlanta, GeorgiaBusiness.govApril 5, 2010

Atlanta is considered anglobal city"alpha-" or "world city",cite webhttp://www.lboro.ac.uk/gawc/world2012t.htmlGaWC – The World According to GaWC 2012Lboro.ac.ukJanuary 13, 2014January 25, 2014ranking 36th among world cities and 8th in the nation with agross domestic productof $270 billion.cite webhttp://www.foreignpolicy.com/node/373401Global Cities 2010: The RankingsForeign PolicyNovember 6, 2010Atlanta's economy is considered diverse, with dominant sectors including logistics, professional and business services, media operations, and information technology.cite webhttp://www.city-data.com/us-cities/The-South/Atlanta-Economy.htmlAtlanta: Economy – Major Industries and Commercial ActivityCity-data.comJuly 16, 2012Topographically, Atlanta is marked by rolling hills andAtlanta tree canopydense tree coverage.cite webGournayIsabelleAIA Guide to the Architecture of AtlantaUniversity of Georgia Presshttp://www.amazon.com/dp/0820314501/refSeptember 28, 2011Smart growthRevitalizationof Atlanta's neighborhoods, initially spurred by the1996 Summer Olympics1996 Olympics, has intensified in the 21st century, altering the city's demographics, politics, and culture.cite webhttp://hdl.handle.net/2142/31169IDEALS @ Illinois: Governmentality: the new urbanism and the creative class within Atlanta, GeorgiaHdl.handle.netMay 22, 2012March 25, 2013cite journalPooleyKaren BeckSegregation's New Geography: The Atlanta Metro Region, Race, and the Declining Prospects for Upward MobilitySouthern SpacesApril 15, 2015http://southernspaces.org/2015/segregations-new-geography-atlanta-metro-region-race-and-declining-prospects-upward-mobility26 May 2015
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: MainHistory of AtlantaSee alsoTimeline of AtlantaPrior to the arrival of European settlers in north Georgia,Creek (people)CreekandCherokee Indiansinhabited the area.cite webhttp://chieftainstrail.com/Northwest Georgia's Native American HistoryChieftains TrailJune 27, 2011Standing Peachtree, a Creek village located wherePeachtree Creekflows into theChattahoochee River, was the closest Indian settlement to what is now Atlanta.cite webUSDM.nethttp://www.atlanta.net/visitors/folklore.htmlAtlanta Trivia Facts and FolkloreAtlanta.netJune 27, 2011As part of the systematic removal of Native Americans from northern Georgia from 1802 to 1825,cite webhttp://ngeorgia.com/history/indianla.htmlLand Cessions of American Indians in GeorgiaNgeorgia.comJune 5, 2007June 27, 2011the Creek ceded the area in 1821,cite webhttp://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?pathNew Georgia Encyclopedia, "Fulton County"Georgiaencyclopedia.orgJune 27, 2011and white settlers arrived the following year.cite webhttp://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?idNew Georgia Encyclopedia, "DeKalb County"Georgiaencyclopedia.orgJune 19, 2008June 27, 2011File:Marietta-Street-Atlanta.jpgthumbleftMarietta Street, 1864In 1836, theGeorgia General Assemblyvoted to build theWestern and Atlantic Railroadin order to provide a link between the port ofSavannah, GeorgiaSavannahand theMidwestern United StatesMidwest.cite webCreation of the Western and Atlantic RailroadAbout North GeorgiaGolden Inkhttp://ngeorgia.com/railroads/warr01.htmlNovember 12, 2007The initial route was to run southward from Chattanooga to a terminus east of the Chattahoochee River, which would then be linked to Savannah. After engineers surveyed various possible locations for the terminus, the "zero milepost" was driven into the ground in what is nowFive Points (Atlanta)Five Points. A year later, the area around the milepost had developed into a settlement, first known as "Terminus", and later as "Thrasherville" after a local merchant who built homes and ageneral storein the area.Thrasherville State Historical Marker, retrieved on November 13, 2009.By 1842, the town had six buildings and 30 residents, and was renamed "Marthasville, GeorgiaMarthasville" to honor theWilson LumpkinGovernor'sdaughter.cite webA Short History of Atlanta: 1782–1859CITY-DIRECTORY, Inc.September 22, 2007http://www.city-book.com/Overview/history/history1.htmDecember 1, 2007J. Edgar Thomson, Chief Engineer of theGeorgia Railroad, suggested the town be renamed "Atlantic OceanAtlantica-Pacific OceanPacifica," which was shortened to "Atlanta".The residents approved, and the town was incorporated as Atlanta on December 29, 1847.cite webhttp://ourgeorgiahistory.com/date/December_29Georgia History Timeline Chronology for December 29Our Georgia HistoryAugust 30, 2007

By 1860, Atlanta's population had grown to 9,554.cite webStoreySteveAtlanta & West Point RailroadGeorgia's Railroad History & Heritagehttp://railga.com/atlwp.htmlSeptember 28, 2007cite webAtlanta Old and New: 1848 to 1868Roadside GeorgiaGolden Inkhttp://roadsidegeorgia.com/city/atlanta02.htmlNovember 13, 2007During theAmerican Civil WarCivil War, the nexus of multiple railroads in Atlanta made the city a hub for the distribution of military supplies. In 1864, following the capture of Chattanooga, theUnion Armymoved southward and began itsAtlanta campaigninvasion of north Georgia. The region surrounding Atlanta was the location of several major armybattles, culminating with theBattle of Atlantaand a four-month-long siege of the city by the Union Army under the command of GeneralWilliam Tecumseh Sherman. On September 1, 1864,Confederate States of AmericaConfederateGeneralJohn Bell Hoodmade the decision to retreat from Atlanta, ordering all public buildings and possible assets to the Union Army destroyed. On the next day, MayorJames Calhounsurrendered Atlanta to the Union Army, and on September 7, General Sherman ordered the city's civilian population to evacuate. On November 11, 1864, in preparation of the Union Army'sSherman's March to the Seamarch to Savannah, Sherman ordered Atlanta to be burned to the ground, sparing only the city's churches and hospitals.cite webA Short History of Atlanta: 1860–1864CITY-DIRECTORY, Inc.September 22, 2007http://www.city-book.com/Overview/history/history2.htmDecember 1, 2007File:AtlantaDuringCivilWar.jpgthumbleftAtlanta in ruins during the Civil War, 1864After the Civil War ended in 1865, Atlanta was gradually rebuilt. Due to the city's superiorrail transportationnetwork, theList of U.S. state historical capitalsstate capitalwas moved to Atlanta fromMilledgeville, GeorgiaMilledgevillein 1868.cite webJacksonEdwin L.The Story of Georgia's Capitols and Capital CitiesCarl Vinson Institute of Government, University of Georgiahttp://www.cviog.uga.edu/Projects/gainfo/capital.htm#anchor671763November 13, 2007https://web.archive.org/web/20071009145856/http://www.cviog.uga.edu/Projects/gainfo/capital.htm#anchor671763October 9, 2007In the 1880 Census, Atlanta surpassed Savannah as Georgia's largest city.Beginning in the 1880s,Henry W. Grady, the editor of theAtlanta Constitutionnewspaper, promoted Atlanta to potential investors as a city of the "New South" that would be based upon a modern economy and less reliant on agriculture. By 1885, the founding of the Georgia School of Technology (nowHistory of Georgia TechGeorgia Tech) and the city's black colleges had established the city as a center for higher education. In 1895, Atlanta hosted theCotton States and International Exposition, which attracted nearly 800,000 attendees and successfully promoted the New South's development to the world.cite newshttp://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?resThe South: Vast Resources, Rapid Development, Wonderful Opportunities for Capital and Labor...[[New York Times]]June 8, 1895

During the first decades of the 20th century, Atlanta experienced a period of unprecedented growth. In three decades' time, Atlanta's population tripled as the city limits expanded to include nearby streetcar suburbs; the city's skyline emerged with the construction of theEquitable Building (Atlanta 1892)Equitable,Flatiron Building (Atlanta)Flatiron,J. Mack Robinson College of Business Administration BuildingEmpire, andCandler Building (Atlanta)Candlerbuildings; andSweet Auburnemerged as a center of black commerce. However, the period was also marked by strife and tragedy. Increased racial tensions led to theAtlanta Race Riotof 1906, which left at least 27 people dead and over 70 injured.cite webhttp://www.1906atlantaraceriot.org/Atlanta Race RiotThe Coalition to Remember the 1906 Atlanta Race RiotSeptember 6, 2006In 1915,Leo Frank, a Jewish-American factory superintendent, convicted of murder, was hanged by alynch mob, drawing attention toantisemitism in the United States.Klapper, Melissa, R., PhD. "20th-Century Jewish Immigration."Teachinghistory.org, accessed February 6, 2012.On May 21, 1917, theGreat Atlanta Fire of 1917Great Atlanta Firedestroyed 1,938 buildings in what is now theOld Fourth Ward, resulting in one fatality and the displacement of 10,000 people.File:Peachtree1907.jpgthumbleftuprightIn 1907, Peachtree Street, the main street of Atlanta, was busy with streetcars and automobiles.On December 15, 1939, Atlanta hosted thefilm premiereofGone with the Wind (film)Gone with the Wind, the epic film based on the best-selling novel by Atlanta'sMargaret Mitchell. The film's legendary producer,David O. Selznick, as well as the film's starsClark Gable,Vivien Leigh, andOlivia de Havillandattended the gala event atLoew's Grand Theatre, but Oscar winnerHattie McDaniel, an African American, was barred from the event due to racial segregation laws and policies.cite webhttp://ngeorgia.com/ang/Atlanta_Premiere_of_Gone_With_The_WindAtlanta Premiere of Gone with the WindNgeorgia.comApril 5, 2010

Atlanta played a vital role in the Allied effort duringWorld War IIdue the city's war-related manufacturing companies, railroad network, and military bases, leading to rapid growth in the city's population and economy. In the 1950s, the city's newly constructed freeway system allowed middle class Atlantans the ability to relocate to the suburbs. As a result, the city began to make up an ever smaller proportion of the metropolitan area's population.cite webhttp://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/articles/counties-cities-neighborhoods/atlantaAtlantaNew Georgia Encyclopedia15 March 200423 July 2015Ambrose, Andy

During the 1960s, Atlanta was a major organizing center of theAfrican-American Civil Rights Movement (19551968)Civil Rights Movement, with Dr.Martin Luther King, Jr.,Ralph David Abernathy, and students from Atlanta'shistorically black colleges and universitiesplaying major roles in the movement's leadership. While minimal compared to other cities, Atlanta was not completely free of racial strife.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?idWhite flight: Atlanta and the making of modern conservatism By Kevin Michael KruseGoogle BooksFebruary 1, 2008June 27, 2011In 1961, the city attempted to thwartblockbustingby erecting road barriers inCascade Heights, countering the efforts of civic and business leaders to foster Atlanta as the "city too busy to hate".cite newshttp://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,874660,00.html"The South: Divided City", ''Time'' magazine, January 18, 1961TIMEJanuary 18, 1963June 27, 2011Desegregation of the public sphere came in stages, with public transportation desegregated by 1959,cite webhttp://dlg.galileo.usg.edu/meta/html/nge/ngen/meta_nge_ngen_h-3664.html?WelcomeBus desegregation in AtlantaDigital Library of Georgiathe restaurant atRich's (department store)Rich'sdepartment store by 1961,cite webhttp://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?idRich's Department Store[[New Georgia Encyclopedia]]movie theaters by 1963,cite webhttp://foxtheatreatlantascrapbook.blogspot.com/2010/05/appendix-19-souths-finest-1946-1969.htmlNegroes Attend Atlanta Theaters[[Atlanta Journal]]May 15, 1962cite webhttp://multimedia.dailyreportonline.com/120anniversary/120_1960.htmlMoments in the 1960sDaily Reportand public schools by 1973.cite webhttp://www.atlantahighered.org/civilrights/essay_detail.asp?phaseAPS TimelineAtlanta Regional Council for Higher EducationFile:JO Atlanta 1996 - Drapeau.jpgthumbThe Olympic flag waves at the 1996 gamesIn 1960, whites comprised 61.7% of the city's population.cite webRace and Hispanic Origin for Selected Cities and Other Places: Earliest Census to 1990U.S. Census Bureauhttp://www.census.gov/population/www/documentation/twps0076/twps0076.htmlJanuary 2, 2012By 1970, African Americans were a majority of the city's population and exercised new-found political influence by electing Atlanta's first black mayor,Maynard Jackson, in 1973. Under Mayor Jackson's tenure, Atlanta's airport was modernized, solidifying the city's role as a transportation center. The opening of theGeorgia World Congress Centerin 1976 heralded Atlanta's rise as a convention city.cite webhttp://www.gwcc.com/about/Fun_Facts.aspxFun FactsGwcc.comJuly 16, 2012Construction of the city'sMetropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authoritysubway systembegan in 1975, with rail service commencing in 1979.cite webhttp://itsmarta.com/about/history02.htmHistory of MARTA – 1970–1979March 2, 2008Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authorityhttps://web.archive.org/web/20050204222807/http://itsmarta.com/about/history02.htmFebruary 4, 2005However, despite these improvements, Atlanta lost over 100,000 residents between 1970 and 1990, over 20% of its population.cite newshttp://roomfordebate.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/10/02/do-olympic-host-cities-ever-win/Do Olympic Host Cities Ever Win? - NYTimes.comRoomfordebate.blogs.nytimes.comOctober 2, 2009July 16, 2012

In 1990, Atlanta was selected as the site for the1996 Summer Olympic Games. Following theBids for the 1996 Summer Olympicsannouncement, the city government undertook several major construction projects to improve Atlanta's parks, sporting venues, and transportation infrastructure. While the games themselves were marred by numerous organizational inefficiencies, as well as theCentennial Olympic Park bombing,cite webOlympic Games Atlanta, Georgia, U.S., 1996Encyclopædia Britannica onlineEncyclopædia Britannicahttp://www.britannica.com/eb/article-249564/Olympic-GamesJanuary 2, 2008they were a watershed event in Atlanta's history, initiating a fundamental transformation of the city in the decade that followed.

During the 2000s, Atlanta underwent a profound transformationdemographicsdemographically, physically, andhuman cultureculturally. Suburbanization, a booming economy, and new migrants decreased the city's black percentage from a high of 67% in 1990 to 54% in 2010.waybackhttp://www.spelman.edu/academics/enrichment/census/pdf/cicnewsletterjan2009vs2.pdf20111208211609U.S. Census BureauFrom 2000 to 2010, Atlanta gained 22,763 white residents, 5,142 Asian residents, and 3,095 Hispanic residents, while the city's black population decreased by 31,678.cite webJimGallowayhttp://blogs.ajc.com/political-insider-jim-galloway/2011/03/23/a-census-speeds-atlanta-toward-racially-neutral-ground/A census speeds Atlanta toward racially neutral ground | Political Insider[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]March 23, 2011July 16, 2012cite newsThe New York TimesShailaDewanMarch 11, 2006Gentrification Changing Face of New Atlantahttp://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/11/national/11atlanta.html?eiMuch of the city's demographic change during the decade was driven by young, college-educated professionals: from 2000 to 2009, theIntown Atlantathree-mile radiussurroundingDowntown Atlantagained 9,722 residents aged 25 to 34 holding at least a four-year degree, an increase of 61%.cite newshttp://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2011-04-01-1Ayoungrestless01_ST_N.htm?sms_ssUSA TodayUrban centers draw more young, educated adultsApril 1, 2011cite webSchneiderCraighttp://www.ajc.com/news/atlanta/young-professionals-lead-surge-907440.htmlYoung professionals lead surge of intown livingajc.comApril 13, 2011June 27, 2011Between the mid-1990s and 2010, stimulated by funding from theHOPE VIprogram, Atlanta demolished nearly all of its public housing, a total of 17,000 units and about 10% of all housing units in the city.cite webhttp://urbanhealth.gsu.edu/files/gsu_public_housing_report1.pdfDeirdre OakleyErin RuelG. Elton WilsonA Choice with No Options: Atlanta Public Housing Residents' Lived Experiences in the Face of Relocation[[Georgia State University]]cite webhttp://www.iut.nu/members/USA/Georgia/ReinventingPublHous2009.pdfHowardHusockReinventing Public Housing: Is the Atlanta Model Right for Your City?[[Manhattan Institute for Policy Research]]US Census Bureau 1990 census total number of housing units in Atlanta cityIn 2005, the $2.8 billionBeltLineproject was adopted, with the stated goals of converting a disused 22-mile freight railroad loop that surrounds the central city into an art-filled multi-use trail and increasing the city's park space by 40%.Atlanta BeltLineLastly, Atlanta's cultural offerings expanded during the 2000s: theHigh Museum of Artdoubled in size; theAlliance Theatrewon aTony Award; and numerous art galleries were established on the once-industrialWest MidtownWestside.cite newshttp://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704415104576250962970106874.html?mod[[The Wall Street Journal]]Timothy W.MartinThe New New SouthApril 16, 2011
article.heading: Geography
article.paragraph: MainGeography of AtlantaAtlanta encompassesconvert347.1sqkmflip, of whichconvert344.9sqkmflipis land andconvert2.2sqkmflipis water.cite webhttp://factfinder2.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/10_DP/G001/1600000US1304000Geographic Identifiers: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (G001): Atlanta city, GeorgiaU.S. Census Bureau, American FactfinderOctober 21, 2015The city is situated among the foothills of the Appalachian Mountains, and atconvert1050ftm0above mean sea level, Atlanta has the highest elevation of major cities east of the Mississippi River.cite webhttp://www.altimeters.net/cityaltitudes.html"Altitudes of Major US Cities," Red Oaks Trading, Ltd.October 28, 2014Atlanta straddles theEastern Continental Divide, such that rainwater that falls on the south and east side of the divide flows into the Atlantic Ocean, while rainwater on the north and west side of the divide flows into theGulf of Mexico.cite webYeazelJackEastern Continental Divide in GeorgiaMarch 23, 2007http://www.gpsinformation.org/jack/Divide/Divide.htmlJuly 5, 2007Atlanta sits atop aridgesouth of theChattahoochee River, which is part of theACF River Basin. Located at the far northwestern edge of the city, much of the river's natural habitat is preserved, in part by theChattahoochee River National Recreation Area.cite webFlorida, Alabama, Georgia water sharingWaterWebsterhttp://www.waterwebster.com/FloridaAlabamaGeorgia.htmnews archiveJuly 5, 2007
article.heading: Cityscape
article.paragraph: MainArchitecture of AtlantaNeighborhoods of AtlantaSee alsoList of tallest buildings in Atlantawide imageAtlanta Downtown Skyline.jpgcenter1000pxThe [[Downtown Atlanta|Downtown]] skylinewide imageTECHATLCL.jpg699pxcenterThe [[Midtown Atlanta|Midtown]] skylinewide imageBuckhead skyline from Vinings.jpg699pxcenterThe [[Buckhead (Atlanta)|Buckhead]] skylineMost of Atlanta was burned during the Civil War, depleting the city of a large stock of its historic architecture. Yet architecturally, the city had never been particularly "southern"because Atlanta originated as a railroad town, rather than aAristocracy (class)patriciansouthern seaport likeSavannah, GeorgiaSavannahorCharleston, South CarolinaCharleston, many of the city's landmarks could have easily been erected in the Northeast or Midwest.File:Midtown HDR Atlanta.jpgthumbThe skyline of Midtown (viewed fromPiedmont Park) emerged with the construction of modernistColony Squarein 1972.During the Cold War era, Atlanta embraced global modernist trends, especially regarding commercial and institutional architecture. Examples ofmodern architecturemodernist architectureinclude theWestin Peachtree Plaza(1976),Georgia-Pacific Tower(1982), theState of Georgia Building(1966), and theAtlanta Marriott Marquis(1985). In the latter half of the 1980s, Atlanta became one of the early adopters of postmodern designs that reintroduced classical elements to the cityscape. Many of Atlanta's tallest skyscrapers were built in the late 1980s and early 1990s, with most displaying tapering spires or otherwise ornamented crowns, such asOne Atlantic Center(1987),191 Peachtree Tower(1991), and theFour Seasons Hotel Atlanta(1992). Also completed during the era is Atlanta's tallest skyscraper, theBank of America Plaza (Atlanta)Bank of America Plaza(1992), which, atconvert1023ftm0, is theList of tallest buildings in the world61st-tallest building in the worldand the 9th-tallest building in the United States. The Bank of America Plaza is the tallest building outside ofNew York CityandChicago, and was the last building built in the United States to be in the top 10 tallest buildings in the world untilOne World Trade Centerwas completed externally on May 2013.cite webhttp://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0001338.htmlWorld's Tallest BuildingsInfopleaseJune 26, 2007The city's embrace of modern architecture, however, translated into an ambivalent approach toward historic preservation, leading to the destruction of notable architectural landmarks, including theEquitable Building (Atlanta 1892)Equitable Building(18921971),Terminal Station (Atlanta)Terminal Station(19051972), and theAtlanta-Fulton Public Library System#The Carnegie LibraryCarnegie Library(19021977). TheFox Theatre (Atlanta, Georgia)Fox Theatre(1929)Atlanta's cultural iconwould have met the same fate had it not been for a grassroots effort to save it in the mid-1970s.

Atlanta is divided into 242 officially definedNeighborhoods of Atlantaneighborhoods.cite webhttp://www.atlantaga.gov/government/planning/neighborhoodlist.aspxCity of Atlanta, "Atlanta Neighborhoods"Atlantaga.govJune 27, 2011cite webhttp://www.atlantadowntown.com/living/neighborhoods"Neighborhoods", Central Atlanta ProgressOctober 28, 2014"MIdtown Atlanta: Neighborhoods", Midtown AllianceThe city contains three major high-rise districts, which form a north-south axis alongPeachtree StreetPeachtree:Downtown AtlantaDowntown,Midtown AtlantaMidtown, andBuckhead (Atlanta)Buckhead.cite webhttp://www.emporis.com/en/wm/ci/bo/?idDistricts and Zones of AtlantaEmporis.comJune 26, 2007Surrounding these high-density districts are leafy, low-density neighborhoods, most of which are dominated by single-family homes.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?idAtlanta: a city of neighborhoods – Joseph F. Thompson, Robert Isbell – Google BooksBooks.google.comJuly 16, 2012

Downtown Atlanta contains the most office space in the metro area, much of it occupied by government entities. Downtown is also home to the city's sporting venues and many of its tourist attractions.Midtown Atlantais the city's second-largest business district, containing the offices of many of the region's law firms. Midtown is also known for its art institutions, cultural attractions, institutions of higher education, and dense form.cite newsSoutherlandRandyWhat do Atlanta's big law firms see in Midtown?Atlanta Business ChronicleNovember 19, 2004http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2004/11/22/focus10.htmlDecember 1, 2008Buckhead (Atlanta)Buckhead, the city's uptown district, is eight miles (13 km) north of Downtown and the city's third-largest business district. The district is marked by an urbanized core alongPeachtree StreetPeachtree Road, surrounded by suburban single-family neighborhoods situated among dense forests and rolling hills.cite newsDAVID KIRBYPublished: November 2, 2003http://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/02/travel/a-tab-of-two-cities-atlanta-old-and-new.html?pagewantedA Tab of Two Cities: Atlanta, Old And New – New York TimesNytimes.comNovember 2, 2003July 16, 2012File:Atlanta etc. 019.jpgthumbCraftsman bungalows inInman ParkFile:Beath-Dickey House 2011.jpgthumbrightBeath-Dickey House(1890) inInman Parkneighborhood, 2011

Surrounding Atlanta's three high-rise districts are the city's low- and medium-densityNeighborhoods of Atlantaneighborhoods,where theAmerican Craftsmancraftsmanbungalowsingle-family home is dominant.[AIA guide to the architecture of Atlanta, edited by Gerald W. Sams, University of Georgia Press, 1993, p. 195]TheEastside (Atlanta)eastsideis marked by historicstreetcar suburbsbuilt from the 1890s-1930s as havens for the upper middle class. These neighborhoods, many of which contain their own villages encircled by shaded, architecturally-distinct residential streets, include theVictorian architectureVictorianInman Park,BohemianismBohemianEast Atlanta, and eclecticOld Fourth Ward.cite newsGreenfieldBethhttp://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?resSURFACING – EAST ATLANTA – The Signs of Chic Are Emerging – NYTimes.comAtlanta (Ga); GeorgiaNew York TimesMay 29, 2005October 16, 2012On theWest Midtownwestside, former warehouses and factories have been converted into housing, retail space, and art galleries, transforming the once-industrialWest Midtowninto a model neighborhood forsmart growth, historic rehabilitation, and infill construction.cite newsDewanShailahttp://travel.nytimes.com/2009/11/22/travel/22surfacing.htmlAn Upstart Art Scene, on Atlanta's West Side – NYTimes.comAtlanta (Ga)Travel.nytimes.comNovember 19, 2009July 16, 2012In southwest Atlanta, neighborhoods closer to downtown originated as streetcar suburbs, including the historicWest End (Atlanta)West End, while those farther from downtown retain a postwar suburban layout, includingCollier HeightsandCascade Heights, home to much of the city's affluent African American population.cite webhttp://www.ajc.com/news/atlanta/atlanta-mayors-race-words-181340.html"Atlanta mayor's race: Words of support", ''Atlanta Journal-Constitution'', November 1, 2009October 28, 2014cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?id"The Black Middle Class: Where It Lives", ''Ebony'', August 1987October 28, 2014cite webhttp://articles.chicagotribune.com/2004-06-27/business/0406270223_1_black-homeowners-neighborhoods-home-buyers/2"Atlanta's minorities see dramatic rise in homeownership", ''Chicago Tribune'', June 27, 2004Chicago TribuneOctober 28, 2014Northwest Atlanta contains the areas of the city to west of Marietta Boulevard and to the north of Martin Luther King, Jr. Drive, including those neighborhoods remote to downtown, such as Riverside, Bolton and Whittier Mill, which is one of Atlanta's designated Landmark Historical Neighborhoods. Vine City, though technically Northwest, adjoins the city's Downtown area and has recently been the target of community outreach programs and economic development initiatives.cite webWheatleyThomashttp://clatl.com/atlanta/wal-mart-and-prince-charles-give-vine-city-a-boost/Content?oidWal-Mart and Prince Charles give Vine City a boost | News & Views | Creative Loafing AtlantaClatl.comDecember 15, 2010July 16, 2012

Gentrification of the city's neighborhoods is one of the more controversial and transformative forces shaping contemporary Atlanta. Thegentrification of Atlantahas its origins in the 1970s, after many of Atlanta's neighborhoods had undergone the urban decay that affected other major American cities in the mid-20th century. When neighborhood opposition successfully prevented twoInterstate 485 (Georgia)freewaysfrom being built through city's the east side in 1975, the area became the starting point for Atlanta'sgentrification. After Atlanta was awarded the Olympic games in 1990, gentrification expanded into other parts of the city, stimulated by infrastructure improvements undertaken in preparation for the games. Gentrification was also aided by theAtlanta Housing Authority's eradication of the city's public housing.cite webSearch Sitehttp://www.city-journal.org/2010/20_4_atlanta-public-housing.htmlAtlanta's Public-Housing Revolution by Howard Husock, City Journal Autumn 2010City-journal.orgJuly 16, 2012
article.heading: Climate
article.paragraph: File:AtlantaSnow.jpgthumbAtlanta'sPiedmont Parkin winterUnder theKppen climate classificationKppen classification, Atlanta has ahumid subtropical climate(Cfa) with four distinct seasons and generous precipitation year-round, typical for the inlandSouthern United StatesSouth. Summers are hot and humid, with temperatures somewhat moderated by the city's elevation. Winters are cool but variable, with an average of 48 freezing days per yearAtlanta, Georgia Travel Weather Averages. Weatherbase. Retrieved on July 12, 2013.and temperatures dropping toconvert0°F1on rare occasions.cite webhttp://voices.yahoo.com/all-time-record-hottest-coldest-temperatures-ever-12114162.html?catAll-time Record Hottest and Coldest Temperatures Ever Recorded in Atlanta – Yahoo! Voicesvoices.yahoo.comJune 10, 2013cite webhttp://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?idNew Georgia Encyclopedia: AtlantaGeorgiaencyclopedia.orgJanuary 5, 2010June 27, 2011Warm air from theGulf of Mexicocan bring spring-like highs while strong Arctic air masses can push lows into the teens ( 7 C).

July averagesconvert80.2°F1, with high temperatures reachingconvert90°F0on an average 44 days per year, thoughconvert100°F0readings are not seen most years.January averagesconvert43.5°F1, with temperatures in the suburbs slightly cooler due largely to theurban heat islandeffect. Lows at or below freezing can be expected 40 nights annually,cite webhttp://www.nws.noaa.gov/climate/xmacis.php?wfoNowData – NOAA Online Weather Data[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]November 30, 2012but extended stretches with daily high temperatures belowconvert40°F0are very rare, with a recent exception inEarly 2014 North American cold waveJanuary 2014. Extremes range fromconvert−9°F0onGreat Blizzard of 1899February 13, 1899toconvert106°F0onSummer 2012 North American heat waveJune 30, 2012.cite webMonthly Averages for Atlanta, Georgia (30303)[[Weather Channel]]Tablehttp://www.weather.com/outlook/travel/businesstraveler/wxclimatology/monthly/graph/30303?fromMarch 23, 2008Dewpoints in the summer range fromconvert63.6°F0in June toconvert67.8°F0in July.

Typical of the southeastern U.S., Atlanta receives abundant rainfall that is relatively evenly distributed throughout the year, though spring and early fall are markedly drier. The average annual rainfall isconvert50.2in3, while snowfall is typically light at aroundconvert2.1incm1per year.cite webhttp://www.sercc.com/climateinfo/historical/avgsnowfall.htmlAverage Total Snowfall (inches) for Selected Cities in the Southeast | Welcome – Southeast Regional Climate CenterSercc.comJune 10, 2013The heaviest single snowfall occurred on January 23, 1940, with aroundconvert10incm0of snow.cite webhttp://www.ourgeorgiahistory.com/chronpop/1000010Our Georgia HistoryAtlanta, Georgia (1900–2000)April 2, 2006However,ice stormsusually cause more problems than snowfall does, the most severe occurring on January 7, 1973. Tornadoes are rare in the city itself, but the March 15, 2008Enhanced Fujita scaleEF2tornadodamaged prominent structures in downtown Atlanta.Atlanta weatherbox
article.heading: Demographics

tablerow.tablecell: Hispanic and Latino AmericansHispanic or Latino(of any race)

article.paragraph: The2010 United States Censusreported that Atlanta had a population of 420,003. Thepopulation densitywas 3,154 persquare mile(1232/square kilometerkm2). The racial makeup and population of Atlanta was 54.0% Black or African American, 38.4% White, 3.1% Asian and 0.2% Native American. Those from some other race made up 2.2% of the city's population, while those from two or more races made up 2.0%. Hispanics of any race made up 5.2% of the city's population.cite webhttp://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/QTTable?_bmDP-1. Profile of General Demographic Characteristics: 2000; Data Set: Census 2000 Summary File 1 (SF 1) 100-Percent Data; Geographic Area: Atlanta city, Georgia, US Census BureauOctober 28, 2014cite webhttp://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?srcProfile of General Population and Housing Characteristics: 2010" (Select Atlanta (city), Georgia), US Census BureauData Access and Dissemination Systems (DADS)October 28, 2014cite webhttp://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/13/1304000.htmlCity of Atlanta Quick Facts, US Census BureauOctober 28, 2014cite webhttp://www.brookings.edu/~/media/Files/rc/reports/2003/11_livingcities_Atlanta/atlanta.pdf"Living Cities" study, Brookings InstitutionThe Brookings InstitutionOctober 28, 2014The median income for a household in the city was $45,171. The per capita income for the city was $35,453. 22.6% percent of the population was living below thePoverty thresholdpoverty line. However, compared to the rest of the country, Atlanta's cost of living is 6.00% lower than the U.S. average. Atlanta has one of the highestLGBTpopulations per capita, ranking third among major American cities, behind San Francisco and slightly behindSeattle, with 12.8% of the city's total population recognizing themselves as gay, lesbian, or bisexual.cite newshttp://seattletimes.nwsource.com/ABPub/zoom/html/2003432941.htmlThe Seattle Times: 12.9% in Seattle are gay or bisexual, second only to S.F., study saysSeattletimes.nwsource.comNovember 15, 2006April 5, 2010Gary J. GatesPDFlink[http://www.law.ucla.edu/williamsinstitute/publications/SameSexCouplesandGLBpopACS.pdf Same-sex Couples and the Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual Population: New Estimates from the American Community Survey]2.07 MB. The Williams Institute on Sexual Orientation Law and Public Policy, UCLA School of Law October 2006.waybackhttp://www.law.ucla.edu/williamsinstitute/publications/SameSexCouplesandGLBpopACS.pdf20140814230029List of U.S. cities by foreign-born population7.3% of Atlantans were born abroad.US Census data as compiled atList of U.S. cities by foreign-born population

In the 2010 Census, Atlanta was recorded as the nation's fourth largest majority black city, and the city has long been known as a center of African American political power, education, and culture, often called ablack mecca."A CHAMPION FOR ATLANTA: Maynard Jackson: 'Black mecca' burgeoned under leader",Atlanta Journal-Constitution, June 29, 2003"the city that calls itself America's 'Black Mecca'"in "Atlanta Is Less Than Festive on Eve of Another 'Freaknik'",Washington Post, April 18, 1996"Atlanta emerges as a center of black entertainment", ''New York Times'', November 26, 2011However,African Americans in AtlantaAfrican American Atlantanshave rapidly suburbanized in recent decades, and from 2000 to 2010, the city's black population decreased by 31,678 people, shrinking from 61.4% of the city's population in 2000 to 54.0% in 2010.cite webWheatleyThomashttp://clatl.com/freshloaf/archives/2011/03/21/atlantas-census-numbers-reveal-dip-in-black-population-and-lots-of-people-who-mysteriously-vanishedThomas Wheatley, "Atlanta's census numbers reveal dip in black population – and lots of people who mysteriously vanished", Creative Loafing, March 21, 2011Clatl.comMarch 21, 2011June 27, 2011

Atlanta has recently undergone a drastic demographic increase in its white population. Between 2000 and 2010, the proportion of whites in the city's population grew faster than that of any other U.S. city. In that decade, Atlanta's white population grew from 31% to 38% of the city's population, an absolute increase of 22,753 people, more than triple the increase that occurred between 1990 and 2000.cite webGurwittRobhttp://www.governing.com/articles/0807atlanta.htmGoverning Magazine: Atlanta and the Urban Future, July 2008Governing.comJuly 1, 2008April 5, 2010

Out of the total population five years and older, 83.3% spoke only English at home, while 8.8% spoke Spanish, 3.9% another Indo-European language and 2.8% an Asian language.U.S. Census 2008 American Community SurveyAtlanta's dialect has traditionally been a variation ofSouthern American English. TheChattahoochee Riverlong formed a border between theSouthern American English#DialectsCoastal SouthernandSouthern American English#DialectsSouthern Appalachiandialects.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?id"Tongue Twisters", ''Atlanta'' magazineBooks.google.comDecember 2003May 17, 2012However, by 2003,Atlanta (magazine)Atlantamagazine concluded that Atlanta had become significantly "de-Southernized", with a Southern accent considered a handicap in some circumstances.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?id"Too Southern for Atlanta", ''Atlanta'' magazineBooks.google.comFebruary 2003May 17, 2012In general, Southern accents are less prevalent among residents of the city and inner suburbs and among younger people, while they are more common in the outer suburbs and among older people;this pattern coexists alongside Southern variations ofAfrican American Vernacular English.

Religion in Atlanta, while historically centered onProtestant Christianity, now involves many faiths as a result of the city and metro area's increasingly international population. While Protestant Christianity still maintains a strong presence in the city (63%),Major U.S. metropolitan areas differ in their religious profiles, Pew Research Centercite webhttp://www.pewforum.org/2015/05/12/americas-changing-religious-landscape/America's Changing Religious Landscape[[Pew Research Center]]: Religion & Public LifeMay 12, 2015in recent decadesRoman Catholic Archdiocese of AtlantaCatholicismhas gained a strong foothold due to migration patterns. Metro Atlanta also has a considerable number of ethnic Christian congregations, including Korean and Indian churches. Large non-Christian faiths are present in the form of Judaism, Islam and Hinduism. Overall, there are over 1,000 places of worship within Atlanta.cite webhttp://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0108481.htmlAtlanta, Ga.Information Please DatabasePearson Education, IncMay 17, 2006
article.heading: Economy
article.paragraph: MainEconomy of AtlantaEncompassing $304 billion, theAtlanta metropolitan areais theList of cities by GDPeighth-largest economy in the country and 17th-largest in the world.cite webhttps://www.ukmediacentre.pwc.com/Content/Detail.asp?ReleaseIDGlobal city GDP rankings 2008–2025Pricewaterhouse CoopersNovember 20, 2009Corporate operations comprise a large portion of the Atlanta's economy, with the city serving as the regional, national, or global headquarters for many corporations. Atlanta contains the country's third largest concentration ofFortune 500companies, and the city is the global headquarters of corporations such asThe Coca-Cola Company,The Home Depot,Delta Air Lines,AT&T Mobility,Chick-fil-A,United Parcel ServiceUPS, andNewell-Rubbermaid. Over 75 percent ofFortune 1000companies conduct business operations in the Atlanta metropolitan area, and the region hosts offices of about 1,250 multinational corporations.cite newshttp://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune500/2011/cities/CNN Money – Fortune Magazine – Fortune 500 2011Many corporations are drawn to Atlanta on account of the city's educated workforce; as of 2010, nearly 43% of adults in the city of Atlanta have college degrees, compared to 27% in the nation as a whole."Betting on Atlanta", EDWARD L. GLAESER, New York TimesFile:Siege-Coke-Atlanta-Nov2007.JPGthumbuprightThe Coca-Cola world headquartersAtlanta began as a railroad town andlogisticshas remained a major component of the city's economy to this day. Atlanta is an important rail junction and contains majorclassification yardsforNorfolk SouthernandCSX TransportationCSX. Since its construction in the 1950s,Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airporthas served as a key engine of Atlanta's economic growth.cite bookAllenFrederickAtlanta Rising1996Longstreet PressAtlanta, Georgia1-56352-296-9Delta Air Lines, the city's largest employer and the metro area's third largest, operates the world's largest airline hub at Hartsfield-Jackson and has helped make it theworld's busiest airport, both in terms of passenger traffic and aircraft operations.cite web[[Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce]]Atlanta's top employers, 2006http://www.metroatlantachamber.com/macoc/business/img/TopEmployers2006.pdfAugust 8, 2007PDFhttps://web.archive.org/web/20070225123824/http://www.metroatlantachamber.com/macoc/business/img/TopEmployers2006.pdfFebruary 25, 2007Partly due to the airport, Atlanta has become a hub for diplomatic missions; as of 2012, the city contains 25 general consulates, the seventh-highestList of diplomatic missions in Atlantaconcentration of diplomatic missionsin the United States.cite webhttp://www.georgia.org/BusinessInGeorgia/InternationalBusiness/Pages/Consulates.aspxConsulates & Consular ServicesGeorgia.orgJune 27, 2011https://web.archive.org/web/20110716041101/http://www.georgia.org/BusinessInGeorgia/InternationalBusiness/Pages/Consulates.aspxJuly 16, 2011no

Media is also an important aspect of Atlanta's economy. The city is a majorcable TVcable televisionprogramming center.Ted Turnerestablished the headquarters of both theCable News Network(CNN) and theTurner Broadcasting System(TBS) in Atlanta.Cox Enterprises, the country's third-largest cable television service and the publisher of over a dozen major American newspapers,cite webAbout CoxCox Communications, Inchttp://www.cox.com/about/August 22, 2007is headquartered in the city."Cox Enterprises, Inc. Reaches Agreement to Acquire Public Minority Stake in Cox Communications, Inc."Cox Enterprises. October 19, 2004. Retrieved on July 4, 2009."City Council Districts." City of Sandy Springs. Retrieved on July 4, 2009."Atlanta Headquarters."Cox Communications. Retrieved on April 22, 2009.The Weather Channel, owned byNBCUniversal,Bain Capital, andThe Blackstone Group, is headquartered just outside of Atlanta inCobb County.

Information technology, an economic sector that includes publishing, software development, entertainment and data processing has garnered a larger percentage of Atlanta's economic output. Indeed, Atlanta has been nicknamed theSilicon peachdue to its burgeoning technology sector. As of 2013, Atlanta contains the fourth-largest concentration of information technology jobs in the United States, numbering 85,000. Atlanta also ranks as the sixth fastest-growing city for information technology jobs, with an employment growth of 4.8% in 2012 and a three-year growth near 9%, or 16,000 jobs. Information technology companies are drawn to Atlanta's lower costs and educated workforce.cite newshttp://www.forbes.com/sites/joelkotkin/2013/05/23/the-cities-winning-the-battle-for-information-jobs/The Cities Winning The Battle For Information JobsForbesApril 18, 2012June 2, 2013JoelKotkincite newshttp://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/print-edition/2011/10/28/growing-our-region-as-high-tech-hub.html?pageGrowing our region as high-tech hub – Atlanta Business ChronicleBizjournals.comOctober 28, 2011June 2, 2013cite webDecember 19, 2012, by tsabulishttp://blogs.ajc.com/atlanta-forward/2012/12/19/technology-thriving/Technology thriving | Atlanta ForwardBlogs.ajc.comDecember 19, 2012June 2, 2013cite webhttp://www.11alive.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyidAtlanta becoming Southeast "Silicon Valley"11alive.comJune 6, 2013June 10, 2013

Largely due to a statewide tax incentive enacted in 2005, theGeorgia Department of Economic Development#Georgia Entertainment Industry Investment ActGeorgia Entertainment Industry Investment Act, which awards qualified productions a transferable income tax credit of 20% of all in-state costs for film and television investments of $500,000 or more,Georgia Department of Economic DevelopmentAtlanta has become aArts in Atlanta#Film and televisioncenter for film and television production. Film and television production facilities in Atlanta includeTurner EntertainmentTurner Studios,Pinewood Studios(Pinewood Atlanta),Tyler Perry Studios,Williams StreetProductions, and theEUE/Screen Gemssoundstages. Film and television production injected $1 billion into Georgia's economy in 2010, with Atlanta garnering most of the projects.cite webhttp://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/print-edition/2011/09/23/film-credit-helping-to-pull-in-1b-in.html?page"Film credit helping to pull in $1B in revenue" ''Atlanta Business Chronicle''September 23, 2011Atlanta Business ChronicleOctober 28, 2014http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/print-edition/2012/03/09/lights-camera-action.htmlhttp://atlantarealestate.citybizlist.com/3/2012/6/10/Study-Atlanta-Ranked-Second-Among-LowestCost-Business-Locations-in-US.aspxAtlanta has gained recognition as a center of production of horror and zombie-related productions,cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/19/us/zombie-apocalypse-in-atlanta.html?_rRobbieBrownZombie Apocalypse? Atlanta Says Bring It OnNew York TimesOctober 18, 2011May 17, 2012withAtlanta (magazine)Atlantamagazine dubbing the city the "Zombie Capital of the World".cite webJustin Heckerthttp://www.atlantamagazine.com/features/story.aspx?IDZombies are so hot right nowAtlantamagazine.comSeptember 2011May 17, 2012cite webGeorge Mathishttp://blogs.ajc.com/news-to-me/2011/10/19/atlanta-the-new-zombie-capital/Atlanta the new 'zombie capitalAtlanta Journal-ConstitutionOctober 19, 2011May 17, 2012File:CNN Atlanta Newsroom.jpgthumbleftThe CNN newsroom

Compared to other American cities, Atlanta's economy has been disproportionately affected by the20072012 global financial crisis2008 financial crisisand subsequent recession, with the city's economy earning a ranking of 68 among 100 American cities in a September 2014 report due to an elevated unemployment rate, declining real income levels, and a depressed housing market.cite webhttp://www.brookings.edu/research/interactives/metromonitor#/M12060, "Metro Monitor - September 2014 - Atlanta - Sandy Springs - Marietta Georgia", Brookings InstitutionSeptember 26, 2014cite webhttp://www.ajc.com/news/news/local/business-boosters-admit-atlanta-in-crisis-amid-eff/nQWmgBusiness boosters admit Atlanta in 'crisis' amid effort to boostJune 12, 2015cite webhttp://www.ajc.com/opinion/new-olympic-moment-1448221.htmlNew Olympic momentJune 12, 2015cite webhttp://www.ajc.com/opinion/hotlanta-isnt-what-it-1317210.html'Hotlanta' isn't what it once wasJune 12, 2015From 20102011, Atlanta saw a 0.9% contraction in employment and only a 0.4% rise in income. Though unemployment had dropped to 7% by late 2014, this was still higher than the national unemployment rate of 5.8%cite webhttp://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/morning_call/2014/11/metro-atlanta-unemployment-rate-falls-to-7-percent.html?pageMetro Atlanta unemployment rate falls to 7 percentNovember 27, 2014Atlanta Business ChronicleJune 12, 2015Atlanta's housing market has also struggled, with home prices falling by 2.1% in January 2012, reaching levels not seen since 1996. Compared with a year earlier, the average home price in Atlanta fell 17.3% in February 2012, the largest annual drop in the history of the index for any city. Atlanta home values average $85,000 as of January 2012, second-lowest among major metropolitan areas, ranking slightly behind Detroit.Citation neededDecember 2014cite webhttp://finance.yahoo.com/news/us-home-prices-drop-6th-130235133.html, "US home prices drop for 6th straight month", Christopher s. Rugaber, Associated PressApril 24, 2012Yahoo FinanceOctober 28, 2014, "In Atlanta, Housing Woes Reflect Nation's Pain", Motoko Rich, New York TimesThe collapse in home prices has led some economists to deem Atlanta the worst housing market in the country.cite webhttp://www.businessinsider.com/atlanta-is-the-worst-housing-market-in-the-country-2012-3PRESENTING: The Worst Housing Market in the CountryPlattEricMarch 27, 2012Business InsiderOctober 28, 2014Nevertheless, in August 2013, Atlanta appeared onForbesmagazine's list of the Best Places for Business and Careers.cite webBest Places For Business and Careers – Forbeshttp://www.forbes.com/best-places-for-business/ForbesJanuary 18, 2014
article.heading: Culture
article.paragraph: File:Museum oF Design Atlanta.jpgthumbThe Museum of Design Atlanta (MODA)File:"Object of Wo(man)" William Massey.jpgthumbPublic art on theBeltLineAtlanta, while located in theSouthern United StatesSouth, has a culture that is no longer strictlyCulture of the Southern United StatesSouthern. This is due to a large population of migrants from other parts of the U.S., in addition to many recentImmigration to the United Statesimmigrants to the U.S.who have made the metropolitan area their home, establishing Atlanta as the cultural and economic hub of an increasinglyMulti-culturalismmulti-culturalmetropolitan area.18.6% of City of Atlanta born in US outside South and 8.0% foreign born (compare to 7.1%/3.0% for Macon, GA and 7.7%/3.2% for Birmingham, AL):PLACE OF BIRTH BY CITIZENSHIP STATUS, 2010 ACS 1-year estimates, U.S. Census American Fact Findercite webGarnerMarcus K.http://www.ajc.com/news/foreign-born-population-continues-780806.htmlForeign-born population continues to grow in metro Atlantaajc.comDecember 18, 2010June 27, 2011Thus, although traditional Southern culture is part of Atlanta's cultural fabric, it is mostly the backdrop to one of the nation's most cosmopolitan cities. This unique cultural combination reveals itself in the arts district of Midtown, the quirky neighborhoods on the city'sEastside (Atlanta)eastside, and the multi-ethnic enclaves found alongBuford Highway.cite webhttp://www.frommers.com/destinations/atlanta/0002010001.htmlIntroduction in Atlanta at Frommer'sFrommers.comJune 27, 2011
article.heading: Arts and theater
article.paragraph: MainArts in AtlantaAtlanta is one of few United States cities with permanent, professional, resident companies in all major performing arts disciplines: opera (Atlanta Opera), ballet (Atlanta Ballet), orchestral music (Atlanta Symphony Orchestra), and theater (theAlliance Theatre). Atlanta also attracts many touring Broadway acts, concerts, shows, and exhibitions catering to a variety of interests. Atlanta's performing arts district is concentrated inMidtown Atlantaat theWoodruff Arts Center, which is home to theAtlanta Symphony Orchestraand theAlliance Theatre. The city also frequently hosts touring Broadway acts, especially at TheFox Theatre (Atlanta, Georgia)Fox Theatre, a historic landmark that is among the highest grossing theatres of its size."1988:Performancemagazine names the Fox Theatre the number one grossing theatre in the 3,0005,000 seat category with the most events, the greatest box office receipts, and the highest attendance in the U.S." and "2009: Billboard magazine names the Fox the No. 1 non-residency theatre for the decade with 5,000 seats or less." on''Timeline'', Fox Theatre website

As a national center for the arts,cite journalTop 25 Big CitiesJenniferClarySummer 2010AmericanStyle Magazine72Atlanta is home to significant art museums and institutions. The renownedHigh Museum of Artis arguably the South's leading art museum and among theList of most visited art museums in the worldmost-visited art museumsin the world.cite webGoldsteinAndrewhttp://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Museum-attendance-rises-as-the-economy-tumbles/19840Museum attendance rises as the economy tumblesThe Art NewspaperJune 27, 2011TheMuseum of Design Atlanta(MODA), a design museum, is the only such museum in the Southeast.waybackhttp://www.museumofdesign.org/about.htm20141218203743Contemporary art museums include theAtlanta Contemporary Art Centerand theMuseum of Contemporary Art of Georgia. Institutions of higher education also contribute to Atlanta's art scene, with the Savannah College of Art and Design's Atlanta campus providing the city's arts community with a steady stream of curators, and Emory University'sMichael C. Carlos Museumcontaining the largest collection of ancient art in the Southeast.cite webhttp://travel.aol.com/travel-guide/united-states/georgia/atlanta-photo-michael-c-carlos-museum-pid-6093735/Michael C. Carlos Museum Pictures, Atlanta, GA – AOL TravelTravel.aol.comJune 27, 2011
article.heading: Music
article.paragraph: File:Tabernacle wide.jpgthumbnailThe stage of the Tabernacle during a live music showMainMusic of AtlantaAtlanta has played a major or contributing role in the development of various genres of American music at different points in the city's history. Beginning as early as the 1920s, Atlanta emerged as a center forcountry music, which was brought to the city by migrants fromAppalachia.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books/about/Pickin_on_Peachtree.html?idWayne W.DanielPickin' on Peachtree: a History of Country Music in Atlanta, GeorgiaBooks.google.comNovember 1, 2000May 17, 20129780252069680During theCounterculture of the 1960scountercultural 1960s, Atlanta hosted theAtlanta International Pop Festival (1969)Atlanta International Pop Festival, with the 1969 festival taking place more than a month beforeWoodstockand featuring many of the same bands. The city was also a center forSouthern rockduring its 1970s heyday: theAllman Brothers Band's hit instrumental "Hot 'Lanta" is an ode to the city, whileLynyrd Skynyrd's famous live rendition of "Free Bird" was recorded at theFox Theatre (Atlanta, Georgia)Fox Theatrein 1976, with lead singerRonnie Van Zantdirecting the band to "play it pretty for Atlanta".cite webhttps://news.google.com/newspapers?idThe Robesonian, Nov. 7, 1976, "Rock's Top Southern Sound Viewed as Lynyrd Skynyrd"October 28, 2014During the 1980s, Atlanta had an activePunk rockscene that was centered on two of the city's music venues,688 Cluband the Metroplex, and Atlanta famously played host to theSex Pistolsfirst U.S. show, which was performed at the Great Southeastern Music Hall.cite webhttp://clatl.com/atlanta/atlanta-punk-a-reunion-for-688-and-metroplex/Content?oidAtlanta punk! A reunion for 688 and MetroplexHenryScottOctober 1, 2008Creative Loafing AtlantaOctober 28, 2014The 1990s saw the birth ofAtlanta hip hop, a subgenre that gained relevance following the success of home-grown duoOutKast; however, it was not until the 2000s that Atlanta moved "from the margins to becoming hip-hop's center of gravity, part of a larger shift in hip-hop innovation to the South".John Caramanica, "Gucci Mane, No Holds Barred ", ''New York Times'', December 11, 2009Also in the 2000s, Atlanta was recognized by the Brooklyn-basedVice (magazine)Vicemagazine for its impressive yet under-appreciatedIndie rockscene, which revolves around the various live music venues found on the city's alternativeEastside (Atlanta)eastside.cite newsRadfordChadDamn hipsters: Is Atlanta falling prey to its indie cachet?Creative LoafingFebruary 25, 2009February 25, 2012cite webHinesJackhttp://www.vice.com/read/intro-100-guide-atlantaThe VICE Guide to AtlantaVICEJuly 16, 2012
article.heading: Tourism
article.paragraph: MainTourism in AtlantaFestivals in AtlantaList of museums in AtlantaCuisine of AtlantaFile:MLK's Boyhood home.jpgthumbleftMartin Luther King, Jr.'s childhood homeFile:WorldofCoca-Cola624.jpgthumbleftTheWorld of Coca-ColaAs of 2010, Atlanta is the seventh-most visited city in the United States, with over 35 million visitors per year.cite newshttp://www.forbes.com/2010/04/28/tourism-new-york-lifestyle-travel-las-vegas-cities_slide_5.htmlForbesValaerMurrayList: America's Most-Visited CitiesAlthough the most popular attraction among visitors to Atlanta is theGeorgia Aquarium,cite webhttp://www.georgiaaquarium.org/members-and-donors/about-us.aspxMembers & Donors | About UsGeorgia AquariumNovember 23, 2005June 27, 2011the world's largest indoor aquarium,cite newsBig window to the seahttp://www.cnn.com/2005/TECH/science/11/21/new.ga.aquarium/index.htmlCNNJanuary 1, 2008November 23, 2005Atlanta's tourism industry mostly driven by the city's history museums and outdoor attractions. Atlanta contains a notable amount of historical museums and sites, including theMartin Luther King, Jr. National Historic Site, which includes the preserved childhood home of Dr.Martin Luther King, Jr., as well as his final resting place; theAtlanta Cyclorama & Civil War Museum, which houses a massive painting anddioramain-the-round, with a rotating central audience platform, depicting theBattle of Atlantain the Civil War; theWorld of Coca-Cola, featuring the history of the world famous soft drink brand and its well-known advertising; theCollege Football Hall of Famewhich honors college football and its athletes; theNational Center for Civil and Human Rights, which explores the American Civil Rights Movement and its connection to contemporary human rights movements throughout the world; theCarter Centerand Presidential Library, housing U.S. PresidentJimmy Carter's papers and other material relating to the Carter administration and the Carter family's life; and theMargaret Mitchell House and Museum, site of the writing of the best-selling novelGone with the Wind.

Atlanta also contains various outdoor attractions.cite webhttp://www.cjnews.com/node/89451Many quiet delights to be found in Atlanta | The Canadian Jewish NewsCjnews.comMarch 2, 2012July 16, 2012TheAtlanta Botanical Garden, adjacent to Piedmont Park, is home to theconvert600ftmmid-longAtlanta Botanical Garden#Canopy WalkKendeda Canopy Walk, aSkywayskywalkthat allows visitors to tour one of the city's last remaining urban forests fromconvert40ftmmid-high. The Canopy Walk is considered the only canopy-level pathway of its kind in the United States.Zoo Atlanta, located inGrant Park (Atlanta)Grant Park, accommodates over 1,300 animals representing more than 220 species. Home to the nation's largest collections of gorillas and orangutans, the Zoo is also one of only four zoos in the U.S. to housegiant pandas.cite webhttp://www.zooatlanta.org/home/history/pandas_to_presentPandas to PresentZooatlanta.orgJune 27, 2011Festivals showcasing arts and crafts, film, and music, including theAtlanta Dogwood Festival, theAtlanta Film Festival, andMusic Midtown, respectively, are also popular with tourists.cite webPark HistoryPiedmont Park Conservancyhttp://www.piedmontpark.org/history/history.htmlJuly 7, 2007https://web.archive.org/web/20070704150329/http://www.piedmontpark.org/history/history.htmlJuly 4, 2007File:The Varsity full meall.jpgthumbrightA meal atThe VarsityTourists are also drawn to the city's culinary scene, which comprises a mix of urban establishments garnering national attention, ethnic restaurants serving cuisine from every corner of the world, and traditional eateries specializing in Southern dining. Since the turn of the 21st century, Atlanta has emerged as a sophisticated restaurant town.cite webhttp://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12923158/ns/travel-24-hour_layover/Frommer's best bets for dining in Atlanta[[MSNBC]]May 30, 2006June 27, 2011Many restaurants opened in the city'sGentrification of Atlantagentrifying neighborhoodshave received praise at the national level, including Bocado, Bacchanalia, and Miller Union inWest Midtown, Empire State South inMidtown AtlantaMidtown, and Two Urban Licks andKevin RathbunRathbun'son theEastside (Atlanta)east side.cite webhttp://www.twourbanlicks.com/sub-acclaim.htmTWO urban licksTWO urban licksJune 27, 2011cite webhttp://www.kevinrathbun.com/details-magazine.htmlDetails Magazine – Official SiteKevinrathbun.comJune 27, 2011cite webhttp://www.thedailybeast.com/galleries/2350/1/America's Hottest New RestaurantsThe Daily BeastNovember 18, 2010June 27, 2011In 2011, theNew York Timescharacterized Empire State South and Miller Union as reflecting "a new kind of sophisticated Southern sensibility centered on the farm but experienced in the city."cite newsSeversonKimhttp://travel.nytimes.com/2011/05/08/travel/08choice-atlanta.htmlAtlanta serves sophisticated SouthernAtlanta (Ga)Travel.nytimes.comMay 6, 2011May 17, 2012Visitors seeking to sample international Atlanta are directed toBuford Highway, the city's international corridor. There, the million-plusimmigrantsthat make Atlanta home have established various authentic ethnic restaurants representing virtually every nationality on the globe.cite webStuartGwyneddhttp://clatl.com/atlanta/highway-to-heaven/Content?oidHighway to heaven | Cover Story | Creative Loafing AtlantaClatl.comJune 24, 2004June 27, 2011For traditional Southern fare, one of the city's most famous establishments isThe Varsity, a long-lived fast food chain and the world's largest drive-in restaurant.cite webThe Varsity: What'll Ya Havehttp://www.thevarsity.com/The VarsityJuly 7, 2007Mary Mac's Tea RoomandPaschal'sare more formal destinations for Southern food.
article.heading: Sports
article.paragraph: MainSports in AtlantaFile:Turner field Braves.jpgthumbTurner FieldAtlanta is home to professional franchises for three major team sports: theAtlanta BravesofMajor League Baseball, theAtlanta Hawksof theNational Basketball Association, and theAtlanta Falconsof theNational Football League. The Braves, who moved to Atlanta in 1966, were established as theBostonRed Stockings in 1871 and are the oldest continually operating professional sports franchise in the United States.citation neededFebruary 2014The Braves won theWorld Seriesin 1995, and had an unprecedented run of 14 straight divisional championships from 1991 to 2005."The Story of the Braves."Atlanta Braves.Retrieved on April 29, 2008.

TheAtlanta Falconshave played in Atlanta since their inception in 1966. The Falcons have won the division title five times (1980, 1998, 2004, 2010, 2012) and the conference championship once, when they finished as the runner-up to theDenver BroncosinSuper Bowl XXXIIIin 1999."History: Atlanta Falcons."Atlanta Falcons.Retrieved on April 29, 2008.waybackhttp://www.atlantafalcons.com/People/Alumni/History.aspx20090225201702TheAtlanta Hawksbegan in 1946 as the Tri-Cities Blackhawks, playing inMoline, Illinois. The team moved to Atlanta in 1968, and they currently play their games inPhilips Arena."A Franchise Rich With Tradition: From Pettit To 'Pistol Pete' To The 'Human Highlight Film'."Atlanta Hawks.Retrieved on April 29, 2008.TheAtlanta Dreamis the city'sWomen's National Basketball Associationfranchise.cite webThe WNBA Is Coming to Atlanta in 2008WNBA.comWNBA Enterprises, LLCJanuary 22, 2008http://www.wnba.com/atlanta/March 21, 2008

Atlanta has also had its own professionalice hockeyandsoccerfranchises. TheNational Hockey League(NHL) has had two Atlanta franchises: theAtlanta Flamesbegan play in 1972 before moving toCalgaryin 1980, while theAtlanta Thrashersbegan play in 1999 before moving toWinnipegin 2011. The Atlanta Chiefs was the city'sNorth American Soccer League (19681984)professional soccerteam from 1967 to 1972, and the team won a national championship in 1968. In 1998 another professional soccer team was formed, theAtlanta Silverbacksof theNorth American Soccer League. In April 2014, aMajor League Soccerteam,Atlanta United FC, was formed as an expansion team to begin play in 2017.

Atlanta has been the host city for various international, professional and collegiate sporting events. Most famously, Atlanta hosted the Centennial1996 Summer Olympics. Atlanta has also hostedSuper Bowl XXVIIIin 1994 andSuper Bowl XXXIVin 2000. In professional golf,The Tour Championship, the finalPGA Tourevent of the season, is played annually atEast Lake Golf Club. In 2001 and 2011, Atlanta hosted thePGA Championship, one of the fourMen's major golf championshipsmajor championshipsin men's professional golf, at theAtlanta Athletic Club. In professional ice hockey, the city hosted the56th National Hockey League All-Star Game56th NHL All-Star Gamein 2008, three years before the Thrashers moved. In 2011, Atlanta hostedprofessional wrestling's annualWrestleMania XXVIIWrestleMania. The city has hosted theNCAA Men's Division I Basketball ChampionshipNCAA Final FourMen's Basketball Championship four times, most recently in2013 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament2013. In college football, Atlanta hosts theChick-fil-A Kickoff Game, theSEC Championship Game, and thePeach BowlChick-fil-A Peach Bowl.cite newshttp://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/print-edition/2011/04/29/atlanta-has-what-it-takes-to-host.html?pageAtlanta has what it takes to host major eventsAtlanta Business ChronicleFebruary 1, 2011DanCorsoApril 29, 2011
article.heading: Parks and recreation
article.paragraph: MainParks in AtlantaFile:Mosaiculture at the Atlanta Botanical Garden.jpgthumbMosaiculture at the Atlanta Botanical GardenFile:Chattahoochee River National Recreation.jpgthumbTheChattahoochee River National Recreation Areain northwestern AtlantaAtlanta's 343 parks, nature preserves, and gardens coverconvert3622acrekm2,cite webhttp://www.atlantaga.gov/index.aspx?page"List of parks, alphabetical", City of AtlantaAtlantaga.govNovember 27, 2011May 17, 2012which amounts to only 5.6% of the city's total acreage, compared to the national average of just over 10%.cite webMcWilliamsJeremiahhttp://www.ajc.com/news/atlanta-parks-system-ranks-1447973.htmlAtlanta parks system ranks below averageajc.comMay 28, 2012July 16, 2012cite webhttp://oldfourthward.11alive.com/news/news/124252-atlanta-parks-get-low-marks-national-surveyAtlanta parks get low marks in national survey | News | Old Fourth Ward NewsOldfourthward.11alive.comJuly 6, 2012July 16, 2012However, 64% of Atlantans live within a 10-minute walk of a park, a percentage equal to the national average.cite webhttp://saportareport.com/blog/2013/06/atlanta-improves-in-national-parkscore-rating-but-still-in-bottom-half-of-u-s-cities/Accessed: 2 July 2013SaportaReportOctober 28, 2014Furthermore, in its 2013 ParkScore ranking, theTrust for Public LandThe Trust for Public Land, a national land conservation organization, reported that among the park systems of the 50 most populous U.S. cities, Atlanta's park system received a ranking of 31."City Profiles: Atlanta""The Trust for Public Land" Retrieved on July 2, 2013Piedmont Park, located inMidtown AtlantaMidtownis Atlanta's most iconic green space. The park, which has undergone a major renovation and expansion in recent years, attracts visitors from across the region and hosts cultural events throughout the year. Other notable city parks includeCentennial Olympic Park, a legacy of the1996 Summer Olympicsthat forms the centerpiece of the city's tourist district;Woodruff Park, which anchors the campus ofGeorgia State University;Grant Park (Atlanta)Grant Park, home to bothZoo Atlantaand theAtlanta Cyclorama & Civil War Museum; andChastain Park, which houses an amphitheater used for live music concerts. TheChattahoochee River National Recreation Area, located in the northwestern corner of the city, preserves aconvert48mionstretch of the river for public recreation opportunities. TheAtlanta Botanical Garden, adjacent to Piedmont Park, contains formal gardens, including a Japanese garden and a rose garden, woodland areas, and a conservatory that includes indoor exhibits of plants fromtropical rainforestsanddeserts. TheBeltLine, a former rail corridor that forms aconvert22mionloop around Atlanta's core, will eventually be transformed into a series ofcity parkparks, connected by a multi-use trail, increasing Atlanta's park space by 40%.cite webKaid Benfieldhttp://grist.org/cities/2011-07-26-the-countrys-most-ambitious-smart-growth-project/The Atlanta BeltLine: The country's most ambitious smart growth projectGristJuly 27, 2011July 16, 2012

Atlanta offers resources and opportunities for amateur and participatory sports and recreation.Joggingis a particularly popular local sport. ThePeachtree Road Race, the world's largestnowrap10 kmrace, is held annually on Independence Day.cite newshttp://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2005/11/14/focus3.htmlPeachtree race director deflects praise to othersAtlanta Business ChronicleJanuary 1, 2008AllisonShirreffsNovember 14, 2005The Georgia Marathon, which begins and ends atCentennial Olympic Park, routes through the city's historic east side neighborhoods.cite webhttp://onlineathens.com/sports/2012-02-11/runners-trek-athens-atlanta-then-run-georgia-marathon-charity"Runners to trek from Athens to Atlanta then run Georgia Marathon for charity" Athens Banner-Herald, Feb. 11, 2012Online AthensOctober 28, 2014Golf and tennis are also popular in Atlanta, and the city contains six public golf courses and 182 tennis courts. Facilities located along the Chattahoochee River cater to watersports enthusiasts, providing the opportunity for kayaking, canoeing, fishing, boating, or tubing. The city's only skate park, aconvert15000sqftm2facility that offers bowls, curbs, and smooth-rolling concrete mounds, is located atHistoric Fourth Ward Park.cite webhttp://www.atlanta.net/reunion/Parks_Info.pdfMicrosoft Word – Parks & Recreation Revised.docPDFOctober 16, 2012
article.heading: Government and politics
article.paragraph: MainGovernment of AtlantaList of mayors of AtlantaCrime in AtlantaFile:City Hall Street Level.jpgthumbleftuprightAtlanta City HallAtlanta is governed by a mayor and theAtlanta City Council. The city council consists of 15 representativesone from each of the city's 12 districts and three at-large positions. The mayor may veto a bill passed by the council, but the council can override the veto with a two-thirds majority.cite webAtlanta City Councilman H Lamar Willis H Lamar Willishttp://www.hlamarwillis.com/CityCouncil.htm June 19, 2009dead linkSeptember 2010H3llBotThe mayor of Atlanta isKasim Reed, a Democrat elected on a nonpartisan ballot whose first term in office expired at the end of 2013. Reed was elected to a second term on November 5, 2013.cite webResults: Atlanta mayor Kasim Reed re-elected to second term Atlanta Journal Constitutionhttp://www.ajc.com/news/news/local/results-atlanta-mayor-kasim-reed-re-elected-second/nbjjN/Every mayor elected since 1973 has been black.cite webLawrence Kestenbaum Mayors of Atlanta, Georgia The Political Graveyardhttp://www.politicalgraveyard.com/geo/GA/ofc/atlanta.html March 7, 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080218193526/http://politicalgraveyard.com/geo/GA/ofc/atlanta.htmlFebruary 18, 2008noIn 2001, Shirley Franklin became the first woman to be elected Mayor of Atlanta, and the first African-American woman to serve as mayor of a major southern city.cite webJosh Fecht and Andrew Stevens Shirley Franklin: Mayor of Atlanta City MayorsNovember 14, 2007 http://www.citymayors.com/usa/atlanta.html January 27, 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20080216164651/http://www.citymayors.com/usa/atlanta.htmlFebruary 16, 2008noAtlanta city politics suffered from a notorious reputation for corruption during the 1990s administration ofBill Campbell (mayor)Bill Campbell, who was convicted by a federal jury in 2006 on three counts of tax evasion in connection with gambling income he received while Mayor during trips he took with city contractors.cite newsAtlanta's former mayor sentenced to prison CNN online CNN June 13, 2006 http://www.cnn.com/2006/LAW/06/13/mayor.sentenced/index.html January 2, 2008

As theList of capitals in the United Statesstate capital, Atlanta is the site of most of Georgia's state government. TheGeorgia State Capitolbuilding, located downtown, houses the offices of theGovernor of Georgiagovernor, lieutenant governor and secretary of state, as well as theGeorgia General AssemblyGeneral Assembly. TheGeorgia Governor's MansionGovernor's Mansionis located in a residential section of Buckhead. Atlanta serves as the regional hub for many arms of the federal bureaucracy, including theFederal Reserve Bank of Atlantaand theCenters for Disease Control and Prevention.cite webCommemorating CDC's 60th AnniversaryCDC WebsiteCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)http://www.cdc.gov/about/history/60th.htmApril 18, 2008cite webhttp://www.gsa.gov/portal/content/101493Georgia Federal BuildingsGsa.govMay 17, 2012Atlanta also plays an important role in federal judiciary system, containing theUnited States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuitand of theUnited States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.

Historically, Atlanta has been a stronghold for theDemocratic Party (United States)Democratic Party. Although municipal elections are officially nonpartisan, nearly all of the city's elected officials are registered Democrats. The city is split between 14 state house districts and four state senate districts, all held by Democrats. At the federal level, Atlanta is split between two congressional districts. The northern three-fourths of the city is located in the 5th district, represented by DemocratJohn Lewis (Georgia politician)John Lewis. The southern fourth is in the 13th district, represented by DemocratDavid Scott (Georgia politician)David Scott.

The city is served by theAtlanta Police Department, which numbers 2,000cite webhttp://www.myajc.com/news/news/local/apd-reaches-a-once-elusive-goal-of-2000-officers/APD reaches a once-elusive goal of 2,000 officersofficers and oversaw a 40% decrease in the city's crime rate between 2001 and 2009. Specifically, homicide decreased by 57%, rape by 72%, and violent crime overall by 55%. Crime is down across the country, but Atlanta's improvement has occurred at more than twice the national rate.cite newshttp://www.ajc.com/opinion/how-to-create-a-711260.htmlHow to create a safer AtlantaDavidEdwardsNovember 1, 2010[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]December 13, 2010https://web.archive.org/web/20101109075330/http://www.ajc.com/opinion/how-to-create-a-711260.htmlNovember 9, 2010noNevertheless, Forbes ranked Atlanta as the sixth most dangerous city in the United States in 2012.cite newshttp://www.forbes.com/sites/danielfisher/2012/10/18/detroit-tops-the-2012-list-of-americas-most-dangerous-cities/Detroit Tops The 2012 List of America's Most Dangerous CitiesForbesOctober 18, 2012October 21, 2012Fisher, Daniel
article.heading: Education

template.arg: List of colleges and universities in metropolitan Atlanta
List of private schools in Atlanta
Tech Tower on the [[Georgia Institute of Technology|Georgia Tech]] campus
Tech Tower on the [[Georgia Institute of Technology|Georgia Tech]] campus
Main Quad on [[Emory University]]'s Druid Hills Campus
Main Quad on [[Emory University]]'s Druid Hills Campus

article.paragraph: Due to the more than 30 colleges and universities located in the city, Atlanta is considered a center for higher education.cite newsAtlanta Business Chroniclehttp://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2003/11/03/daily8.html?jstAtlanta a magnet for young, single, educated – Atlanta Business ChronicleBizjournals.comNovember 3, 2003July 16, 2012Among the most prominent public universities in Atlanta is theGeorgia Institute of Technology, a research university located inMidtown AtlantaMidtownthat has been consistently ranked among the nation's top ten public universities for its degree programs in engineering, computing, management, the sciences, architecture, and liberal arts.Georgia State University, a public research university located inDowntown Atlanta, is the second largest of the 35 colleges and universities in the University System of Georgia and a major contributor to the revitalization of the city's central business district. Atlanta is also home to nationally renowned private colleges and universities, most notablyEmory University, a leading liberal arts and research institution that ranks among the top 20 schools in the United States and operatesEmory Healthcare, the largest health care system inGeorgia (U.S. state)Georgia.cite webhttp://www.emoryhealthcare.org/about-us/index.htmlAbout Emory HealthcareEmory HealthcareAugust 3, 2011Also located in the city is theAtlanta University Center, the largest contiguous consortium ofHistorically black colleges and universitieshistorically black colleges, comprisingSpelman College,Clark Atlanta University,Morehouse College,Morehouse School of Medicine, andInterdenominational Theological Center. Atlanta also contains a campus of theSavannah College of Art and Design, a private art and design university that has proven to be a major factor in the recent growth of Atlanta's visual art community.

Atlanta Public Schoolsenrolls 55,000 students in 106 schools, some of which are operated as charter schools.School Stats, Retrieved June 9, 2010.The district has been plagued by a widely publicizedAtlanta Public Schools cheating scandalcheating scandalexposed in 2009. Atlanta is also served by many private schools, including parochial Roman Catholic schools operated by theArchdiocese of Atlanta.
article.heading: Media
article.paragraph: MainMedia in AtlantaThe primary network-affiliated television stations in Atlanta areWXIA-TV(NBC),WGCL-TV(CBS),WSB-TV(ABC), andWAGA-TV(FOX). The Atlanta metropolitan area is served by two public television stations and one public radio station.WGTVis the flagship station of the statewideGeorgia Public Televisionnetwork and is aPublic Broadcast ServicePBSmember station, whileWPBA (TV)WPBAis owned byAtlanta Public Schools. Georgia Public Radio is listener-funded and comprises oneNPRmember station,WABE, a classical music station operated byAtlanta Public Schools.

Atlanta is served by theAtlanta Journal-Constitution, its only major daily newspaper with wide distribution.
