TheAtlanta Journal-Constitutionis the result of a 1950 merger betweenThe Atlanta JournalandThe Atlanta Constitution, with staff consolidation occurring in 1982 and separate publication of the morningConstitutionand afternoonJournalceasing in 2001.cite webhttp://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?idNew Georgia Encyclopedia: Atlanta Journal-ConstitutionGeorgiaencyclopedia.orgJuly 16, 2012Alternative weeklynewspapers includeCreative Loafing (Atlanta)Creative Loafing, which has a weekly print circulation of 80,000.Atlanta (magazine)Atlantamagazine is an award-winning, monthly general-interest magazine based in and covering Atlanta.
article.heading: Transportation
article.paragraph: MainTransportation in AtlantaFile:ATL airport interior.jpgthumbConcourse B at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, the world's busiest airportFile:Bright Atlanta.jpgthumbTheDowntown Connector, seen at night in Midtown.Atlanta's transportation infrastructure comprises a complex network that includes aheavy railline, astreetcarline, multiple interstate highways, the world's busiest airport, and overconvert45mi0offof bike paths.

With a network of freeways that radiate out from the city, automobiles are the dominant mode of transportation in the region.cite webAtlanta: Smart Travel TipsFodor'sFodor's Travelhttp://www.fodors.com/miniguides/mgresults.cfm?destinationSeptember 28, 2007https://web.archive.org/web/20071018043200/http://fodors.com/miniguides/mgresults.cfm?destinationOctober 18, 2007noThree majorinterstate highwaysconverge in Atlanta:Interstate 20I-20(east-west),Interstate 75I-75(northwest-southeast), andInterstate 85I-85(northeast-southwest). The latter two combine in the middle of the city to form theDowntown Connector(I-75/85), which carries more than 340,000 vehicles per day and is one of the most congested segments of interstate highway in the United States.cite newshttp://www.forbes.com/2006/02/06/cx_bm_0207trafficslide_6.html?thisSpeedWorst City Choke Points, ForbesAtlanta, I-75 at I-85April 2, 2006February 6, 2006Atlanta is mostly encircled byInterstate 285, abeltwaylocally known as "the Perimeter" that has come to mark the boundary between "Inside the Perimeter" (ITP), the city and close-in suburbs, and "Outside the Perimeter" (OTP), the outer suburbs and exurbs. The heavy reliance on automobiles for transportation in Atlanta has resulted in traffic, commute, and air pollution rates that rank among the worst in the country.cite newsCopelandLarryAtlanta pollution going nowhereUSA TODAYGannett Co. IncJanuary 31, 2001http://www.usatoday.com/weather/news/2001/2001-01-31-atlanta-pollution.htmSeptember 28, 2007cite newsAtlanta traffic the worst in Americahttp://atlanta.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2008/04/28/daily97.htmlMay 1, 2008cite webhttp://www.bryancountynews.net/archives/4754/Forbes says Atlanta now most polluted city in U.SBryancountynews.netNovember 11, 2009July 16, 2012

TheMetropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority(MARTA) provides public transportation in the form of buses and heavy rail. Notwithstanding heavy automotive usage in Atlanta, the city'srapid transitsubwaysystem is theList of United States Rapid Transit systems by Ridershipeighth busiest in the country.American Public Transportation Association,Heavy Rail Transit Ridership Report, Fourth Quarter 2007.MARTA rail lines connect many key destinations, such as the airport, Downtown, Midtown, Buckhead, and Perimeter Center. However, significant destinations, such as Emory University andCumberland, GeorgiaCumberland, remain unserved. As a result, a 2012Brookings Institutionstudy placed Atlanta 87th of 100 metro areas for transit accessibility.cite webhttp://www.brookings.edu/research/papers/2012/07/11-transit-jobs-tomer/~/media/Research/Files/Papers/2012/7/transit%20labor%20tomer/pdf/Atlanta.pdf"Atlanta-Sandy Springs-Marietta, GA Metro Area", part of "Missed Opportunity: Transit and Jobs in Metropolitan America", Brookings InstitutionPDFJune 2012July 17, 2012Emory Universityoperates itsThe Cliff (Emory)Cliffshuttle buses with 200,000 boardings per month, while privateminibusesplyBuford Highway.Amtrak, the national rail passenger system, provides service to Atlanta via theCrescent (train)Crescent train(New YorkNew Orleans), which stops atPeachtree Station.http://www.amtrak.com AmtrakIn 2014, theAtlanta Streetcaropened to the public. The streetcar's line, which is also known as the Downtown Loop, runs 2.7 miles around the downtown tourist areas ofPeachtree Center,Centennial Olympic Park, theMartin Luther King, Jr. National Historic Site, and Sweet Auburn.cite webAtlanta Streetcarhttp://streetcar.atlantaga.gov/The Atlanta Streetcar line is also being expanded on in the coming years to include a wider range of Atlanta's neighborhoods and important places of interest, with a total of 66 miles of track being laid in the near future.citation neededMarch 2015

Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, the world's busiest airport as measured byWorld's busiest airports by passenger trafficpassenger trafficandWorld's busiest airports by traffic movementsaircraft traffic,cite webJimTharpehttp://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/stories/2007/01/04/0104airport.htmlAtlanta airport still the "busiest": Hartsfield-Jackson nips Chicago's O'Hare for second year in a row[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]January 4, 2007https://web.archive.org/web/20070106042352/http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/stories/2007/01/04/0104airport.htmlJanuary 6, 2007September 28, 2007offers air service to over 150 U.S. destinations and more than 80 international destinations in 52 countries, with over 2,700 arrivals and departures daily.cite webhttp://www.atlanta-airport.com/Airport/ATL/ATL_FactSheet.aspx"ATL Fact Sheet", Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International AirportAtlanta-airport.comMay 17, 2012Delta Air Linesmaintains its largest hub at the airport.cite webhttp://news.delta.com/index.php?sDelta Invites Customers to Improve Their Handicap with New Service to Hilton Head, Expanded Service to Myrtle BeachNews.delta.comApril 5, 2010Situatednowrap10 miles(nowrap16 km) south of downtown, the airport covers most of the land inside a wedge formed byInterstate 75,Interstate 85, andInterstate 285.

Cycling in AtlantaCyclingis a growing mode of transportation in Atlanta, more than doubling since 2009, when it comprised 1.1% of all commutes (up from 0.3% in 2000).cite webDudaClayhttp://clatl.com/atlanta/atlanta-becoming-a-bike-friendly-city/Content?oidAtlanta is on the road to becoming a bike-friendly city | News Feature | News & Views | Creative Loafing AtlantaClatl.comNovember 23, 2011October 16, 2012cite webhttp://www.theatlanticcities.com/commute/2011/09/substantial-increases-bike-ridership-across-nation/161/Is Bicycle Commuting Really Catching On? And if So, Where? - CommuteThe Atlantic CitiesSeptember 16, 2011October 16, 2012Although Atlanta's lack of bike lanes and hilly topography may deter many residents from cycling,cite webDudaClayhttp://clatl.com/atlanta/atlantas-cycling-community-needs-some-help/Content?oidAtlanta's cycling community needs some help | Opinion | Creative Loafing AtlantaClatl.comJune 30, 2010October 16, 2012the city's transportation plan calls for the construction ofconvert226mi0offof bike lanes by 2020, with the BeltLine helping to achieve this goal.cite webDudaClayhttp://clatl.com/atlanta/atlanta-cycling-statistics/Content?oidAtlanta cycling statistics | Cover Story | Creative Loafing AtlantaClatl.comJuly 1, 2010October 16, 2012In 2012, Atlanta's first "bike track" was constructed on 10th Street in Midtown. The two lane bike track runs from Monroe Drive west to Charles Allen Drive, with connections to the Beltline and Piedmont Park.cite web10th Street Cycle Trackhttp://beltline.org/2013/07/24/10th-street-cycle-track/
article.heading: Tree canopy

template.arg: For a sprawling city with the nation's ninth-largest metro area, Atlanta is surprisingly lush with trees—[[magnolia]]s, [[Cornus (genus)|dogwoods]], [[Pine|Southern pines]], and magnificent [[oak]]s.
''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'' magazine, in naming Atlanta a "Place of a Lifetime"<ref name

article.paragraph: Atlanta has a reputation as a "city in a forest" due to an abundance of trees that is rare among major cities.cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/22/us/22trees.html[[The New York Times]]RobbieBrownAtlanta Finds Its Identity as Tree Haven Is ThreatenedJuly 21, 2011cite webJeanne Bonnerhttp://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wabe/news.newsmain/article/0/6/1619579/Science/Atlanta%27s.tree.canopy.at.riskWABE: Atlanta's tree canopy at risk (March 4, 2010)Publicbroadcasting.netMarch 4, 2010June 27, 2011cite webhttp://www.frommers.com/destinations/atlanta/0002010001.htmlIntroduction to AtlantaWiley Publishing, Inc.Frommer'sJune 26, 2007cite webhttp://www.atlantamagazine.com/article.php?idCity Observed: Power PlantsSeptember 28, 2007WarhopBillAtlanta Magazinehttps://web.archive.org/web/20070607192757/http://www.atlantamagazine.com/article.php?idJune 7, 2007cite webhttp://www.10best.com/destinations/georgia/atlanta/Atlanta Travel Guide: Atlanta, GA City Guide from10BestJune 27, 2011The city'sPeachtree Streetmain streetis named after aPeachtree, and beyond the Downtown, Midtown, and Buckhead business districts, the skyline gives way to a dense canopy of woods that spreads into the suburbs. The city is home to theAtlanta Dogwood Festival, an annual arts and crafts festival held one weekend during early April, when the nativeCornus (genus)dogwoodsare in bloom. However, the nickname is also factually accurate, as the city's tree coverage percentage is at 36%, the highest out of all major American cities, and above the national average of 27%.cite webhttp://www.deeproot.com/blog/blog-entries/tree-cover-how-does-your-city-measure-upTree Cover % – How Does Your City Measure Up?DeepRoot BlogApril 25, 2010June 27, 2011Atlanta's tree coverage does not go unnoticedit was the main reason cited byNational Geographic (magazine)National Geographicin naming Atlanta a "Place of a Lifetime".cite webhttp://travel.nationalgeographic.com/city-guides/atlanta-georgia/Atlanta, Georgia – National Geographic's Ultimate City GuidesTravel.nationalgeographic.comJune 27, 2011

The city's lush tree canopy, which filters out pollutants and cools sidewalks and buildings, has increasingly been under assault from man and nature due to heavy rains, drought, aged forests, new pests, and urban construction. A 2001 study found that Atlanta's heavy tree cover declined from 48% in 1974 to 38% in 1996.cite webhttp://www.treenextdoor.org/index.php?optionChanges in Atlanta's Tree CanopyTreenextdoor.orgOctober 30, 2008June 27, 2011However, the problem is being addressed by community organizations and city government:Trees Atlanta, a non-profit organization founded in 1985, has planted and distributed over 75,000 shade trees in the city,cite webAbout UsTrees Atlantahttp://www.treesatlanta.org/aboutus.htmlSeptember 28, 2007https://web.archive.org/web/20070922033545/http://www.treesatlanta.org/aboutus.htmlSeptember 20, 2010while Atlanta's government has awarded $130,000 in grants to neighborhood groups to plant trees.
article.heading: Sister cities

template.arg: List of sister cities in the United States

article.paragraph: Atlanta has 18 sister cities, as designated bySister Cities International, Inc.
